THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL BE PUBLISHED IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLE AND PRESENTED AT A SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE. THE TOOL WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ONLINE FOR BROAD COMMUNITY USE. THE TECHNIQUE AND ASSOCIATED TOOL COULD ALLOW SIMPLE AND FAST ESTIMATES OF RIVER DISCHARGE USING ONLY REMOTE SENSING IMAGERY. THIS COULD BOTH SUPPLEMENT DIRECT FLOW MEASUREMENTS AND PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF FLOW IN RIVERS THAT ARE DIFFICULT OR DANGEROUS TO DIRECTLY ACCESS. SUCH DISCHARGE INFORMATION IS ESSENTIAL TO PLAN INFRASTRUCTURE (E.G., ROADS, BRIDGES, CULVERTS, LEVEES) DESIGN, PARTICULARLY FOR FLOODING HAZARDS.

PROJECT TITLE  TOWARDS ACCESSIBLE, OPEN, AND ACCURATE REMOTE SENSING OF WATER QUALITYPROJECT PERIOD  FEBRUARY 1, 2023 THROUGH JANUARY 31, 2025RELIABLE, REPRODUCIBLE, AND TIMELY ESTIMATES OF INLAND WATER QUALITY FROM REMOTE SENSING CAN PROVIDE FOUNDATIONAL INSIGHT TO IMPROVE WATER MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, EMPOWER STAKEHOLDERS TO MONITOR THEIR WATERBODIES, AND HELP SCIENTISTS BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW INLAND WATERBODIES ARE CHANGING. HOWEVER, USING REMOTE SENSING TO PRODUCE ROBUST ESTIMATES OF KEY WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS LIKE CHLOROPHYLL A (A PROXY FOR ALGAL BIOMASS), SEDIMENT CONCENTRATIONS, DISSOLVED ORGANIC CARBON, AND OVERALL WATER CLARITY REQUIRES A HARMONIZED, CLEAN, AND ANALYSIS READY GROUND TRUTH DATASET. ONE SUCH DATASET IS AQUASAT, A DATABASE OF MORE THAN 600,000  MATCHUPS  THAT PAIR IN SITU WATER QUALITY GRAB SAMPLES WITH SURFACE REFLECTANCE DATA FROM LANDSAT 5, 7, 8 DATA OVER THE CONTINENTAL UNITED STATES (ROSS ET AL. 2019). THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED WORK IS TO DRAMATICALLY EXPAND AND IMPROVE AQUASAT IN THREE CRUCIAL WAYS. FIRST, THE PROJECT WILL INCORPORATE MORE IN SITU DATA FROM WATER QUALITY SENSORS, OPTICALLY INACTIVE CONSTITUENTS LIKE NUTRIENTS, AND MORE DATA SOURCES FROM THE WATER QUALITY PORTAL AND ADDITIONAL DATA SOURCES (E.G., LAGOS USA  SORANNO ET AL. 2015). SECOND, THE PROJECT WILL CREATE A DATA QUALITY TIERING SYSTEM TO ADDRESS ISSUES IN THE ORIGINAL DATASET  RESTRICTIVE DATA THAT IS VERIFIABLY SELF SIMILAR ACROSS ORGANIZATIONS AND TIME PERIODS AND CAN BE CONSIDERED COMPLETELY INTERCHANGEABLE  NARROWED DATA THAT WE HAVE GOOD REASON TO BELIEVE IS SELF SIMILAR, BUT FOR WHICH WE CAN T VERIFY FULL HARMONY ACROSS DATA PROVIDERS  INCLUSIVE DATA, THE CURRENT LEVEL OF DATA PROVIDED BY AQUASAT, WHERE DATA ARE ASSUMED TO BE RELIABLE AND HARMONIZED UNLESS OBVIOUS DIFFERENCES EXIST. THIRD, THE PROJECT WILL ADD NEW SATELLITES AND SPECTRAL BANDS TO OUR MATCHUP DATABASE, INCLUDING SENTINEL 2, MODIS AQUA, AND SENTINEL 3. ALL OF THESE ADDITIONAL SATELLITES OR CONSTELLATIONS OF SATELLITES HAVE POTENTIAL USE FOR REMOTE SENSING OF WATER QUALITY, AND THIS NEW WORK WILL ADD THEM TO THE AQUASAT DATABASE. THESE IMPROVEMENTS, ALONG WITH TUTORIALS AND WORKSHOPS DEVELOPED BY THE PROJECT, WILL ENABLE RESEARCHERS TO MORE EASILY AND RELIABLY OBSERVE WATER QUALITY PATTERNS AT UNPRECEDENTED SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES.

PROJECT TITLE  STANDARDIZING SOFTWARE AND PROCESSES FOR IMAGE VELOCIMETRY GAUGING METHODSPROJECT PERIOD  JANUARY 1, 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2024OBTAINING RIVER DISCHARGE MEASUREMENTS DURING FLOODING EVENTS HAVE LONG BEEN A CHALLENGING AND DANGEROUS TASK IN THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES WHERE FLASHY FLOW HAS HIGH VELOCITY AND HIGH SEDIMENT CONCENTRATION. IMAGE VELOCIMETRY METHODS OFFER THE ABILITY TO ESTIMATE FLOW DISCHARGE THROUGH IMAGES CAPTURED REMOTELY FROM CAMERAS ON THE GROUND OR MOUNTED ON UNOCCUPIED AIRCRAFT SYSTEMS (UAS) OR SATELLITES. IMAGE VELOCIMETRY METHODS TEND TO SHARE FOUR MAJOR STEPS  IMAGE ACQUISITION, PRE PROCESSING, PROCESSING USING A TRACKING METHOD, AND POST PROCESSING FROM SURFACE FLOW PROPERTIES TO DISCHARGE. ALTHOUGH MANY RESEARCH AND APPLICATIONS ARE REPORTED IN LITERATURE, THE TOOLS FOR DATA ACQUISITION AND ANALYSIS HAVE NOT BEEN STANDARDIZED. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO STANDARDIZE THE DATA ANALYSIS TOOLS FOR CALCULATING SURFACE FLOW PROPERTIES AND ESTIMATING FLOW DISCHARGE. FIRST, RESEARCHERS WILL SEARCH FOR HIGH QUALITY VIDEO FOOTAGE REPRESENTING RIVERS OF DISTINCT GEOMORPHIC SETTINGS FROM AN ACCESSIBLE DATA REPOSITORY (I.E. USGS REMOTE SENSING DATABASE). SECOND, RESEARCHERS WILL STANDARDIZE INPUT AND OUTPUT DATA FORMATS USING OPEN SOURCE LANGUAGE. THIRD, RESEARCHERS WILL ANALYZE AND COMPARE THE OUTPUTS FROM PROCESSING VIDEO FOOTAGE USING SEVERAL IMAGE VELOCIMETRY ALGORITHMS INCLUDING LARGE SCALE PARTICLE IMAGE VELOCITY (LSPIV), PARTICLE TRACKING VELOCIMETRY (PTV), SPACE TIME IMAGE VELOCIMETRY (STIV), SURFACE STRUCTURE IMAGE VELOCIMETRY (SSIV), AND OPTICAL TRACKING VELOCIMETRY (OTV). FOURTH, RESEARCHERS WILL USE DIFFERENT METHODS TO ESTIMATE FLOW DISCHARGE FROM MEAN AND TURBULENCE PROPERTIES AT THE SURFACE. THE METHODS INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO LOGARITHMIC LAW, POWER LAW, CONSTANT ?, TURBULENCE DISSIPATION RATE, AND ENTROPY. THE RESULTS WILL BE COMPARED WITH GAUGE OBSERVATIONS FOR EVALUATING THE ACCURACY OF EACH APPROACH. THE RESEARCHERS EXPECT TO PRODUCE SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS AS WELL AS STANDARDIZED SOFTWARE TOOLS AND DATASETS. THIS PROJECT WILL BE CLOSELY COLLABORATED WITH USGS SCIENTISTS TO ENSURE THE TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER UPON THE COMPLETION OF PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND DELIVERABLES. THE INTENDEDBENEFICIARIES ARE RESEARCHERS COLLECTING FLOW STAGE AND DISCHARGE DATA. THE IMAGE BASED METHOD CAN POTENTIALLY REPLACE THE TRADITIONAL STAGE DISCHARGE RATING CURVES CURRENTLY USED IN THE FIELD.

TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM   TEXASBORDER WATER RESOURCES  THE ROLE OF GROUNDWATER IN CREATING RESILIENCY AND WATER SECURITYPROJECT PERIOD  11 14 2022 THROUGH 09 24 2027AWARD PURPOSE  THE U.S.-MEXICO TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM  TAAP  REPRESENTS A COLLABORATION AMONG THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY  USGS  WATER SCIENCE CENTERS  WSC  AND THE WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH INSTITUTES  WRRI  OF ARIZONA, NEW MEXICO, AND TEXAS. THE U.S. AND MEXICAN STATE DEPARTMENTS, THROUGH THE INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY AND WATER COMMISSION  IBWC CILA , FACILITATE BILATERAL PROJECTS AND COLLABORATION WITH MEXICAN UNIVERSITIES AND FEDERAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE NATIONAL WATER COMMISSION  CONAGUA  AND THE WATER TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE  IMTA . THE ACT DIRECTS THE USGS AND WRRI TO CONDUCT HYDROGEOLOGIC CHARACTERIZATION, MAPPING, AND MODELING OF PRIORITY TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS IN GROUNDWATER-DEPENDENT BORDER COMMUNITIES SUBJECT TO STRESS FROM DEVELOPMENT AND DROUGHT. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED 1. STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING  INFORM STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING RESOURCE MANAGERS AND DECISIONMAKERS, ABOUT PREVIOUS WORK AND PERCEPTIONS. THEN ASK ABOUT THEIR CURRENT PRIORITIES AND BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN STAKEHOLDER GROUPS VIA TRAININGS AND PRESENTATIONS TO AID THEM IN ADDRESSING FUTURE PROBLEMS WITH ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL TOOLS AND KNOWLEDGE. 2. SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONTEXT, GOVERNANCE, AND POLICY  UPDATE UNDERSTANDING OF EXISTING SOCIAL, POLITICAL, CULTURAL, AND ECONOMIC FRAMEWORKS THAT SHAPE THE USE AND MANAGEMENT OF SHARED GROUNDWATER IN PRACTICE ALONG THE U.S. MEXICO BORDER. 3. BINATIONAL GROUNDWATER ATLAS  DATA MANAGEMENT, MAPPING, AND VISUALIZATION  ACCESS TO DATA, DATA VISUALIZATION, AND ANALYSIS IS CRITICAL TO SUPPORT STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING RESOURCE MANAGERS, DECISION-MAKERS, AND SCIENTISTS WORKING ALONG THE BORDER. WE WILL CREATE AN INTERACTIVE BINATIONAL ATLAS, MAPPING, AND DATA VISUALIZATION PLATFORM TO SUPPORT UNDERSTANDING AND EXPLORATION OF TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS BY DECISIONS MAKERS, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND PRIVATE CITIZENS. 4. AQUIFER PRIORITIZATION AND VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT  TIME AND GROUNDWATER SCARCITY ARE PRESSING CHALLENGES ALONG THE 1,800 MILE STRETCH OF BORDER BETWEEN TEXAS-NEW MEXICO-ARIZONA AND MEXICO. GIVEN THE IMMENSITY OF THE TASK AND THE SCARCITY OF RESOURCES, THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED FOR PRIORITIZATION OF TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS FOR STUDY. TO ACHIEVE THIS, WE WILL USE THE TOOLS AND INFORMATION DEVELOPED IN PREVIOUS STEPS  BINATIONAL DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, UPDATED UNDERSTANDING OF GOVERNANCE AND SOCIOECONOMIC CONTEXT, AND THE NETWORK OF STAKEHOLDERS   TO DEVELOP A FLEXIBLE FRAMEWORK FOR PRIORITIZATION OF TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS FOR STUDY ALONG THE U.S.-MEXICO BORDER. 5. HYDROLOGIC STUDIES TO UNDERSTAND WATER AVAILABILITY CHALLENGES FACING TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS   STRESSORS FROM POPULATION, INDUSTRY, AGRICULTURE, DROUGHT, AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY  USING THE PRIORITIES AND INSIGHT DEVELOPED IN THE PREVIOUS TASKS, TOOLS MUST BE DEVELOPED TO HELP DECISION-MAKERS AND WATER AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON WATER RELIABILITY FOR BORDERLAND COMMUNITIES. METHODS BEING CURRENTLY IMPLEMENTED OR EXPANDING IN USE INCLUDE MANAGED AQUIFER RECHARGE, LIMITATIONS ON WATER USE, AND INCREASING THE REUSE OF TREATED WATER. HOWEVER, LIMITED INFORMATION HAS BEEN GATHERED ABOUT THESE EFFORTS AND THE SITES WHERE THEY ARE LOCATED AND THE POSSIBLE IMPACTS ON TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS. TO SUPPORT DECISION-MAKERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, WE WILL CARRY OUT HYDROLOGIC STUDIES  FIELD INVESTIGATIONS, MODELING, AND ASSESSMENTS OF UNCERTAINTY  TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF WATER AVAILABILITY AND RISKS TO WATER SUPPLIES ALONG THE U.S.-MEXICO BORDER.

TITLE  TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM   NM WRRI EFFORT FY2022 2027PROJECT PERIOD  12 14 2022 THROUGH 09 24 2027ABSTRACTTHE TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (TAAP) IS CONGRESSIONALLY AUTHORIZED TO CONDUCT BINATIONAL SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH TO ASSESS PRIORITY AQUIFERS ALONG THE U.S. MEXICO BORDER. INVESTIGATIONS ARE BEING CONDUCTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND THE BORDER WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH INSTITUTES (WRRI) IN ARIZONA, NEW MEXICO, AND TEXAS, AND IN COLLABORATION WITH STATE AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS, MEXICAN COUNTERPARTS AND THE INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY AND WATER COMMISSION. THE PURPOSE OF TAAP IS TO GENERATE SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE ABOUT BINATIONALLY SHARED GROUNDWATER RESOURCES THAT ARE CRITICAL TO COMMUNITIES, ECONOMIES, AND ECOLOGIES IN THE BORDERLANDS. EACH YEAR NM WRRI FUNDS MULTIPLE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES THROUGH TAAP FUNDING, INCLUDING TOPICS OF  THE CULTURAL, POLITICAL, AND ECONOMIC DRIVERS OF WATER USE  MODELING OF BINATIONAL AQUIFERS  AQUIFER RECHARGE  AND GEOCHEMICAL WATER ANALYSES. BEYOND SCIENTIFIC ANALYSES, TAAP GOALS INCLUDE WORKING WITH MEXICAN COUNTERPARTS TO EXCHANGE DATA AND COLLABORATE ON SCIENTIFIC STUDIES. TAAP FUNDING IS THEREFORE ALSO USED TO PARTICIPATE IN OFFICIAL TAAP MEETINGS AND DATA EXCHANGES, AND TO FOSTER COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE U.S. AND MEXICO ON BINATIONAL AQUIFER STUDIES, INCLUDING HOSTING A BINATIONAL GROUNDWATER SCIENCE CONVERSATION SERIES, AND HOSTING BINATIONAL GROUNDWATER CONFERENCES. AS PART OF THE ANNUAL TAAP PROPOSAL PREPARED BY NM WRRI AND SUBMITTED TO USGS, EACH RESEARCH ACTIVITY PROPOSED INCLUDES EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES. THESE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE GENERATION OF DATA SETS, MODELS, PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, TECHNICAL RESEARCH REPORTS, AND PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS OF RESEARCH FINDINGS. FOR ACTIVITIES INTENDED TO FOSTER BINATIONAL COLLABORATION, DELIVERABLES INCLUDE DATA SETS EXCHANGED WITH MEXICAN COUNTERPARTS, AND NUMBERS OF PARTICIPANTS IN BINATIONAL EVENTS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF TAAP RESEARCH AND COLLABORATIVE ACTIVITIES ARE STAKEHOLDERS WHO DEPEND ON BINATIONAL GROUNDWATER RESOURCES, THE BINATIONAL COMMUNITY OF SCIENTISTS WHO STUDY TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS, AND THOSE INVOLVED IN POLICYMAKING AND GOVERNANCE EFFORTS. TAAP FUNDING AT NM WRRI ALSO SUPPORTS EARLY CAREER RESEARCHERS AND FUNDS GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCH AND EDUCATION.

PROJECT TITLE  TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (TAAP)  ARIZONA WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH CENTER EFFORTPROJECT PERIOD  12 8 2022 THROUGH 9 24 2027THE WORK PROPOSED BY THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH CENTER IS PART OF THE BINATIONAL UNITED STATES MEXICO TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (TAAP). THE ARIZONA WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH CENTER S SPECIFIC FOCUS IS ON THE SAN PEDRO AND SANTA CRUZ BINATIONAL AQUIFERS, WHICH ARE TWO OF THE FOUR AQUIFERS OF FOCUS SPECIFIED BY U.S. PUBLIC LAW 109 448. YEAR 1 OF THIS FIVE YEAR PROGRAM INVOLVES FIVE TASKS  1) COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS IDENTIFIED THROUGH THE TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER ASSESSMENT PROGRAM COOPERATIVE FRAMEWORK, 2) HYDROLOGIC AND HYDROGEOLOGIC CHARACTERIZATIONS, 3) TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER RECONNAISSANCE WORK, 4) SOCIOECONOMIC CHARACTERIZATION OF SELECTED BORDER COMMUNITIES, AND EXAMINATION OF MODES OF GOVERNANCE, AND 5) STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT. THE FIRST TASK OF YEAR 1 INVOLVES COMPLETING THE BINATIONAL STUDY OF THE TRANSBOUNDARY SANTA CRUZ AQUIFER AND COLLABORATING IN BINATIONAL AND REGIONAL MEETINGS. YEAR 1 S SECOND TASK CONSISTS OF MONITORING EFFORTS IN THE ARIZONA SONORA AQUIFERS OF FOCUS AND ASSESSING THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND WATER MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ON GROUNDWATER AVAILABILITY. YEAR 1 S THIRD TASK INVOLVES WORKING ON AN INVENTORY AND GAP ANALYSIS OF AVAILABLE TRANSBOUNDARY WATER DATA. YEAR 1 S FOURTH TASK IS CHARACTERIZING SELECTED BORDER COMMUNITIES  SOCIOECONOMIC CONTEXT. FINALLY, YEAR 1 S FIFTH TASK CONSISTS OF MAINTAINING AND INCREASING STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS TO IMPROVE THE KNOWLEDGE BASE ABOUT THE ARIZONA SONORA TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFERS. ADDITIONAL PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES OF THIS FIVE YEAR PROGRAM INCLUDE  1) ASSESSING THE IMPACT OF LAND COVER CHANGES IN THE ARIZONA SONORA AQUIFERS OF FOCUS, 2) WATER BALANCE MODELING EFFORTS FOR THE SAN PEDRO AND SANTA CRUZ RIVER BASINS, 3) ASSESSING THE UNCERTAINTY ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRANSBOUNDARY SAN PEDRO AND SANTA CRUZ BASIN MODELS, 3) PLANNING FOR FUTURE BINATIONAL GROUNDWATER MODELING EFFORTS FOR THE ARIZONA SONORA AQUIFERS OF FOCUS, 4) MANAGEMENT, MAPPING, AND VISUALIZATION OF TRANSBOUNDARY WATER DATA, AND 5) TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER PRIORITIZATION AND VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT. THE ANALYSIS AND REPORTS PRODUCED THROUGH THIS EFFORT CONTINUE THE WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH CENTER S COLLABORATIVE PARTICIPATION IN THE ASSESSMENT OF TRANSBOUNDARY GROUNDWATER RESOURCES, WITH THE WORK CONTRIBUTING TO IMPROVED CHARACTERIZATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF TRANSBOUNDARY AQUIFER AND GROUNDWATER CONDITIONS AND EFFECTIVE DISSEMINATION OF FINDINGS BINATIONALLY.

PHYSICS-INFORMED MACHINE LEARNING FOR PARAMETER ESTIMATION AND SURROGATE MODELINGAWARD PERIOD: 8/16/2022 THROUGH 8/15/2024AWARD PURPOSE: THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED AWARD IS TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED DATA-DRIVENMODELING CAPABILITIES WITH PHYSICS-INFORMED CONSTRAINTS. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL ADVANCE METHODSFOR INTEGRATING DATA AND MODELS USING THE STATE-OF-THE-ART PHYSICS-INFORMED MACHINE LEARNINGMETHODS TO IMPROVE THE ACCURACY OF MODEL PREDICTIONS THROUGH BETTER MODEL PARAMETERIZATIONAND UNCERTAINTY QUANTIFICATION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WE WILL DEVELOP: (1) PHYSICS-INFORMED MACHINE LEARNING (PIML)PARAMETER ESTIMATION METHODS AND (2) PIML SURROGATE MODELS. RECENTLY, WE PROPOSED SEVERALPIML METHODS FOR ESTIMATING PARAMETERS AND STATES, SUCH AS HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY, HYDRAULICHEAD, AND CONCENTRATION FIELDS. IN THESE METHODS, THE UNKNOWN PARAMETER FIELDS AND STATEVARIABLES ARE MODELED WITH DEEP NEURAL NETWORKS (DNN) OR CONDITIONAL KARHUNEN-LOEVE (KL)EXPANSIONS THAT ARE FUNCTIONS OF TIME AND/OR SPACE COORDINATES. THEN, THE COEFFICIENTS IN THESEEXPANSIONS ARE ESTIMATED BY MINIMIZING AN OBJECTIVE (OR LOSS) FUNCTION THAT HAS TWO PARTS: THE"DATA" PART (A DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE PARAMETER AND STATE MODELS AND MEASUREMENTS) AND THE"PHYSICS" PART THAT IS THE SUM OF RESIDUAL OF THE GOVERNING EQUATIONS AT SEVERAL POINTS IN THEDOMAIN THAT ARE COMPUTED USING AUTOMATIC DIFFERENTIATION (AD). THE MAIN ADVANTAGE OF THESEPARAMETER ESTIMATION METHODS IS THAT THERE IS NO NEED TO DISCRETIZE AND SOLVE EQUATIONS TOMINIMIZE THE LOSS FUNCTION. OUR PRELIMINARY RESULTS SHOW THAT THE PIML-BASED PARAMETERESTIMATION METHODS CAN BE ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE FASTER THAN TRADITIONAL PARAMETER ESTIMATIONMETHODS SUCH AS THE MAXIMUM A POSTERIORI (MAP) METHOD. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL EXTEND THEPIML METHODS TO MULTISCALE PROBLEMS. WE WILL ALSO DEVELOP SURROGATE MODELS BASED ON THE PIML METHODS. THE DNN MODEL OF THE SYSTEM STATES WILL INCLUDE INITIAL AND BOUNDARY CONDITIONS AND SOURCE TERMS IN ADDITION TO THE SPACE AND TIME VARIABLES. THE MAIN ADVANTAGE OF THE PIML METHODS FOR CONSTRUCTING SURROGATE MODELS OVER OTHER METHODS (INCLUDING STANDARD "DATA-DRIVEN" ML METHODS) IS THAT THEY REQUIRE A RELATIVELY SMALL AMOUNT OF DATA FOR TRAINING. THIS IS BECAUSE THE PHYSICS CONSTRAINTS ALLOW TO FILL "GAPS" IN DATA AND MAKE THE SURROGATE MODELS MORE ACCURATE FOR INTERPOLATION. WE WILL FOCUS ON SURROGATE MODELS WHERE INPUTS ARE FUNCTIONS RATHER THAN A FINITE NUMBER OF PARAMETERS THAT COULD BE AN OUTPUT OF CLIMATE OR SOCIO-ECONOMIC MODELS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: WE WILL DELIVER A COMPUTATIONAL FRAMEWORK FOR PARAMETERESTIMATION AND SURROGATE MODELING THAT CAN BE INTEGRATED WITH EXISTING COMPUTATIONAL MODELS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE BROADER COMPUTATIONAL GEOSCIENCES COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING ADVANCES COMPUTATIONAL TOOLS FOR MODEL PARAMETERIZATION AND DEVELOPING SURROGATE MODELS.

STOCHASTIC WEATHER GENERATION FOR CLIMATE SCENARIO DEVELOPMENT ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES BASINPROJECT PERIOD: 4/15/2022 THROUGH 4/14/2023PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD THE DEVELOPMENT OF A STOCHASTIC WEATHER GENERATOR THAT CAN CREATE ENSEMBLES OF CLIMATE SCENARIOS ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. THE WEATHER GENERATOR WILL BE DESIGNED TO DEVELOP LONG TRACES OF WEATHER THAT CAN BE DIRECTLY INPUT INTO DOWNSTREAM MODELS OF GREAT LAKES WATER LEVELS, INCLUDING MODULES FOR RAINFALL-RUNOFF AND LAKE EVAPORATION. THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES WILL BE PERFORMED UNDER THIS PROJECT: 1) SELECT OBSERVATIONAL RECORD(S) FOR USE IN THE STOCHASTIC WEATHER GENERATOR; 2) CONSULT ON THE DATA, CALIBRATION, AND EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN SURROUNDING THE USE OF DOWNSTREAM WATER LEVEL MODELS; 3) ADVISE ON THE DESIGN OF A VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE SELECTION OF FUTURE SCENARIOS AND SPECIFICATION OF CONTROL SCENARIOS; 4) CREATE BASELINE STOCHASTIC WEATHER DATA AS INPUTS FOR CURRENT CONDITION LAKE LEVEL MODELS; 5) CREATE A SET OF FUTURE CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS CONTAINING WEATHER DATA AS INPUTS FOR THE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT; AND 6) DEVELOP AND COMPILE REPORTS, MEMORANDUMS, PRESENTATIONS AND OTHER INFORMATION TO DOCUMENT MODEL DEVELOPMENT. THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE A SET OF CLIMATE SCENARIOS FOR THE GREAT LAKES UNDER BASELINE (NO CLIMATE CHANGE) CONDITIONS, AS WELL AS A SET OF CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS THAT REFLECT PLAUSIBLE PATHWAYS OF FUTURE WARMING OVER THE GREAT LAKES, ALONG WITH ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE COASTAL COMMUNITIES ALONG THE GREAT LAKES, WHO CAN USE THIS INFORMATION TO ASSESS THE VULNERABILITY OF INFRASTRUCTURE AND OTHER PROJECTS ALONG THE SHORELINE TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

TITLE: MAPPING FIELD-LEVEL IRRIGATION SYSTEM TYPE AND TRENDS TO ENABLE IMPROVED AGRICULTURAL WATER USE ESTIMATION ACROSS THE UNITED STATESPROJECT PERIOD: 05/01/2022 THROUGH 04/30/2025SPATIAL INFORMATION ABOUT AGRICULTURAL IRRIGATION SYSTEM TYPES AND THEIR LOCATIONS COULD HELPIMPROVE THE MODELING AND MANAGEMENT OF IRRIGATED WATER USE, EFFICIENCY, AND WITHDRAWALS. THE OUTPUTS WILL BE USEDTO SUPPORT AND IMPROVE ONGOING ANALYSES OF IRRIGATION WATER USE AND EFFICIENCY ANDULTIMATELY ENABLE MORE EFFECTIVE WATER MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND DECISION-MAKING ATMULTIPLE SCALES FROM FARM TO NATION. BENEFICIARIES ARE LOCAL, STATE, AND REGIONAL WATER GOVERNANCE BODIES,AGRIBUSINESSES, AND THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY.

REMOTELY-SENSED WATER QUALITY OF MICHIGAN LAKES: ANALYSIS OF LAKE WATER CLARITY AND ALGAL BIOMASS USING LANDSAT 8 AND SENTINEL 2 SATELLITE IMAGERYPROJECT PERIOD: APRIL 1, 2022 THROUGH MARCH 31, 2024AWARD PURPOSE: USING RECENTLY DEVELOPED STATE-OF-THE-ART REMOTE SENSING TECHNIQUES CALIBRATED AND VALIDATED WITH AVAILABLE WATER QUALITY MONITORING DATA (WATER CLARITY, CHLOROPHYLL, AND COLOR) FROM ROUTINE SAMPLING AND CITIZEN MONITORING, LAKE WATER QUALITY WILL BE PREDICTED FOR ALL MICHIGAN LAKES GREATER THAN 20 ACRES IN SURFACE AREA BY APPLYING MODELS TO ALL AVAILABLE CLEAR SENTINEL 2 AND LANDSAT 8 IMAGERY FOR THE ICE-FREE SEASON OF MAY - OCTOBER FROM 2018-2022 AND WOULD PROVIDE DAILY ESTIMATES OF LAKE-LEVEL WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS WHEN CLEAR IMAGERY ARE AVAILABLE, AND MONTHLY AVERAGES / MOSAICS OF DATA.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA HAS AUTOMATED THE IMAGE PROCESSING PROCEDURES USING THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA SUPERCOMPUTERS, ALLOWING FOR THE RAPID ANALYSIS OF ALL AVAILABLE LANDSAT 8 AND SENTINEL 2 SATELLITE IMAGERY AND MAXIMIZING THE AMOUNT OF WATER QUALITY DATA THAT IS AVAILABLE FOR LAKE AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. RESULTING PIXEL AND LAKE LEVEL WATER QUALITY PRODUCTS WILL BE INCORPORATED BY USGS INTO A DATA DASHBOARD WITH ENHANCED COMMUNICATION ATTRIBUTES COMMON TO AN ARCGIS EXPERIENCE BUILDER APPLICATION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE MINNESOTA LAKEBROWSER PROVIDES AN EXAMPLE OF THE DATA THAT WILL BE PRODUCED THROUGH THIS PROJECT. DUE TO THE CLOUD COVER IN OUR STATES, WE DETERMINED THAT MONTHLY OPEN WATER (MAY THROUGH OCTOBER) PIXEL LEVEL MOSAICS WORK BEST FOR STATEWIDE COVERAGE. LAKE LEVEL DATA WILL BE DETERMINED FOR EACH CLEAR IMAGE OCCURRENCE AND COMPILED IN CSV FILES THAT CAN BE USED TO CALCULATE WATER QUALITY STATISTICS FOR DIFFERENT TIMEFRAMES (E.G. MONTHLY, SUMMER (JUNE-SEPT)) AND LINKED TO A LAKE POLYGON LAYER THAT CAN BE USED FOR GEOSPATIAL ANALYSIS AND INCLUDED IN A WEB MAP INTERFACE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY: THE EXPERIENCE BUILDER APPLICATION WILL PROVIDE MICHIGAN ENVIRONMENT, GREAT LAKES, AND ENERGY (EGLE) STAFF WITH THE DESIRED PUBLIC COMMUNICATION TOOL NECESSARY TO ENHANCE AND SUSTAIN MANAGEMENT OF LAKE WATER QUALITY IN MICHIGAN.
